Ray has built a strong following and reputation for his in depth analysis of the chip space as well as his strong coverage of semiconductors and companies around the world.
We look forward to having Ray lend his expertise to our large semiconductor client base as well as our broad audience.

The futures market is more orderly, and reflecting tensions elevated for sure (despite no change in supply) but the options market is completely out of control. The key driver seems to be that enormous macro fund bought close to 100k brent u25 95 calls and holds all the cards. So far has not sold any seemingly. So dealer inventory effect is hugely apparent. This trade seems to be an inflationary hedge.

Iran has made a lot of noise about closing the strait of hormuz but that would actually hurt them primarily, as they need cash to fund a war and also probably lead to allies abandoning them. Also unclear if they even can, with some of those waters in Oman. So they would have to escalate the conflict towards their neighbors, not israel. It's all incredibly messy.

So far there has been no disruption to Iran supply/output, the energy assets israel has attacked are all internal. so kharg island is the big export loading station, and that is a very easy target and completely untouched so far, which clearly says something

The tension about what happens next in the Middle East is making its presence felt. Look no further than Crude Oil options: -oil options market is quite disorderly. vol spike for sure but liquidity is totally shot üßµ

4 Questions to Ask Yourself Before 6:30 a.m. Every Day

#1: Why Am I Even Awake?

You need time to get your head together in the morning. Big winning days start in the premarket, not at 9:30 am.

#2: Am I Ready to Execute With Confidence?

A clear plan for action gives you the mental edge you need to react in the moment. The more you plan, the faster you can move.

#3: Do I Know What‚Äôs on the Calendar?

The price action brings plenty of surprises on its own. So know what‚Äôs happening, and how it all affects your positions.

#4: Am I Watching Scott Redler‚Äôs #630club?

I go live Monday to Thursday at 6:30 am ET to get you ready for the day. 

100% free on X/Twitter and YouTube.

Arnold Schwarzenegger, a legal immigrant, successful actor, and former California Governor, just left The View STUNNED. 

They attempted to get him to condemn ICE raids and what did he do? 

He credited America for his success, promoted legal immigration, and called out violent criminal aliens. 

Absolute masterclass: 

‚ÄúI'm so proud and happy that I was embraced by the American people like that. Imagine I came over here with absolutely nothing, and then to create a career like that. In no other country in the world could you do that. Every single thing is because of America.‚Äù

MAY ‚Äò25 @SMBCAPITAL TAKEAWAYS

1. Product selection matters. Given the macro environment and opportunity set, many traders adapted by expanding into futures and options to capture the full range of opportunities. Oftentimes, the expected value of certain setups via options far exceeds that in the equity. Yes there‚Äôs a learning curve, but worthwhile for experienced traders.

2. Daily chart filtering became a huge edge once market structure confirmed further upside. The best traders proactively scanned for continuation patterns and structured trades around them. Personally, this has always been a weaker area for me and something even I could do a much better job at.

A lot of the swing traders on here like @RealSimpleAriel and others are far more adept at this than I am.

3. If you hit a PNL PR in a month like June, which imo was far less opportunistic than May, odds aren‚Äôt it wasn‚Äôt just getting lucky. You leveled up. When your process gets sharper and you extract more from less, that‚Äôs growth in its purest form.

4. Trading is really hard. You really need to be ok with getting the crap knocked out of you again and again. In order to do that, you do need to find a way to enjoy the process. Yes, there will always be absolutely awful moments of doubt and frustration. But if you can‚Äôt find a way to be motivated and appreciative of the experience‚Ä¶. It just isn‚Äôt going to happen or trading is meant to be a hobby. And that is totally ok too!

5. I was absolutely floored by the quality of intern at SMB this year. These interns were only a few weeks in and they could have passed for full-time traders 3 months into the learning curve.
